pages.text: Teraterpeton hrynewichorum comes from the Upper Triassic, with fossils found in the Wolfville Formation, Nova Scotia (Canada). It is a medium-sized archosauromorph, growing up to 2 m in length. It is incredibly unique in having a elongated, thin skull with no teeth at the ends of the jaws but many small interlocking teeth at the back of the jaws. It also bore a large nasal opening and a closed up fenestra, like that of marine reptiles.

The generic name derives from the Greek words 'teras', to mean 'wonder'; and 'erpeton', to mean 'creeping thing'. The specific name derives from the Latinised surname of George P. & Sandy Hrynewich, the discoverers of the first fossil specimens.
